title: Tuesday, 30th January, 2018

11:02 am

Anyway, I've spent much of the morning feeling a even more dumb than usual. Because ......

rwl ...put it politely, it's all a dog's brexit :)

BE11:07am

Under a comprehensive free trade agreement with the EU, UK growth would be 5% lower over the next 15 years compared to current forecasts, according to the analysis.
The "no deal" scenario, which would see the UK revert to World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, would reduce growth by 8% over that period. The softest Brexit option of continued single-market access through membership of the European Economic Area would, in the longer term, still lower growth by 2%.

BE11:07am

Okay, what do these two paragraphs actually mean?

Otter The meaning of the first sentence which mentions negative conclusions in 'every scenario modelled' is rather different to what is suggested by the headline's mention of 'every scenario'
Paper Chase Agreed. They may as well be forecasting lottery numbers.
Rick Chasey DCB; because it was the current (pro brexit) gov't that issued the report. Surely they ought to be honest about what they've been doing and the information they're receiving.
BE11:07am

Leaving aside the "pft, forecasts!" angle for a moment, what do these numbers mean?

11:07 am
BE11:07am

What does "UK growth would be (2%, 5% or 8%) lower over the next 15 years compared to current forecasts" actually mean?

BE11:08am

As in: if X = current 15 year forecasts, what are the scenarios X minus 2%, 5% or 8%? Or are they X minus 2, 5 or 8 percentage points?

J L Morning
BE11:09am

I get that the economic toll of Brexit varies 2% to 8% over 15 years. But without actually seeing the fan chart the numbers have been cribbed from, I can't force my brain to make sense of them?

11:09 am
BE11:09am

ROTR, you're a lot smarter than me. Can you help me out here?

luzh Agree that it's confusing. What is "growth" usually measured in? % change in GDP?
Pernaffo I think it's X *0.98, *0.95 and *0.92 respectivelybut that's just my guessX - 8% doesnt make sense in my mind
undefined
red economic forecasts 15yrs out is something you cannot sensibly plot or at least give any credence to numbers. so anything u extrapolate from that...

Pernaffo where X is GDP in 15 years
wayneJ There has been some overnight chatter that these forecasts are better than George Osbornes / Treasury forecasts in Project Fear; BUT these forecasts include the assumption the UK gets FTA with the US and various other countries - if you strip those out these look close to the original Treasury forecasts.
Are we there yet Basically we will be worse off than staying - but thats the price the BREXITERs are willing for us to pay

BE11:18am

As well as detailing the operational/strategic rationale for
the deal (scale, global research, higher proportion of predictable revenue streams, operational synergies etc.), Informa has confirmed it anticipates £60m of annual recurring pre-tax cost savings, with around £50m to be delivered in 2019. In our recent notes (Recreating History: Potential Informa and UBM Merger), we assumed c. £40m of savings by 2020E, so this is ahead of our initial estimates, and equates to c. 3% of the combined cost base. The £60m will be split as follows: £20m of corporate overhead reduction, £37m of management and support restructuring (including de-duplicating of IT/systems etc.) and £3m of procurement benefits. We note that the company has said it has identified further potential cost saving opportunities, but these have not been quantified by the auditors. One-off cash costs of £80m are anticipated in order to implement these synergies. Although the press release alludes to potential revenue synergies, these have not been quantified (under take-over rules)

wayneJ Also the EU actually allows for restrictions on Freedom of Movement - if only we had had a Home Secretary who actually walked the walk
SoS @WayneJ well that would increase the GDP figures
BE11:19am

We continue to think the deal makes strategic sense for Informa, although we do question the timing of the deal (particularly given the recent strong share price for UBM). Does this deal signal that Informa management too have some concerns around the longer-term growth potential of these non-Events businesses and therefore feel under pressure to buy into areas of higher growth in order to sustain momentum going forward? We rate Informa Neutral. We also downgraded UBM to Neutral yesterday (29 th Jan) as we feel that the current share price/valuation does not warrant fresh money.

Tsetse As a remainer, it occurred to me that maybe the largest short to medim term threat to the EU isn't the UK leaving, it's the UK leaving successfully. Even if Brexit's the mess we think it'll be, inevitably there will come a time when the UK is on the up and the EU is on the down - I think that's when some pipsqueaks try to jump. If you think the EU is treating us like we're trying to leave the scientologists, wait until one of the minnows tries it on..

BE11:28am

Based on Factset forecasts, the deal equates to CY19E/20E EV/Sales, EV/EBITDA and PE multiples of 6.0x/5.8x, 18.9x/17.7x and 33.8x/31.3x respectively, which compares favourably to BTG, which is trading on 4.5x/4.4x sales, 16.6x/15.1x EBTIDA and 15.0x/23.3x EPS (in same years). However, we would note that BTG is a diversified business, with only 26% of FY18E revenues and perhaps less of EBITDA coming from the IO business with the company generating a significant proportion of Group profit from Zytiga and continued exceptional performance from the Pharmaceuticals business (31% of revenues and 53% of contribution) that are low growth (relative) and have patent cliffs approaching. Utilising the EV/Sales acquisition multiples seen with Sirtex would equate to a valuation of c.£800m for BTG’s TheraSphere business and £960m for its IO division, which includes TheraSphere, Biocompatibles (same concept but using chemotherapy) and Galil (cryoablation business), which is above the valuation we have in our model (£870m). Overall, we see the valuation read across as neutral for BTG's own IO division, which is arguably near full value.

BE11:29am

Overall, we think the deal is potentially negative from a competitive standpoint for BTG, given the products will now be in the hands of a well-capitalised peer who has considerable experience targeting the US hospital space with its suite of radiotherapy, radiosurgery, proton therapy and brachytherapy assets. This compares to Sirtex, who had recently lost its CEO on insider trading charges and undoubtedly taken its eye off the ball with growth stalling in recent years. The market is high growth, and perhaps space for more than one player, but with more financial muscle, and perhaps more focus on the SIR-Spheres we could see more competition to BTG.

BE11:38am

Total revenues were £641mn, up 53.6% reported and 7.2% LFL. Note that the Peacock acquisition in the US closed at the end of December 2016 and was not in Q1 2017 numbers. UK revenues were £385 mn, up 9.2% (LFL of 8.7%), with food-to-go revenues up 12.2% (LFL of 11.4%). This is much ahead of the growth reported by the supermarkets (mid single-digit growth), and remains the driver of the group. We have FY18 food-to-go revenues up 7%. Company continues to benefit from contract wins over FY17 (Sainsbury). UK – rest had revenues up 5.7% (LFL of 5.5%), we have full year estimate of 2% revenue growth (ex the capacity closure in Evercreech which happens later in the year). Company announced yesterday the sale of its Hull facility that made cakes and desserts – this is the right move strategically, in our view, and should improve growth dynamics in UK – rest over long term. US revenues were £255mn, up 297%, with LFL of 5.1% and volume growth of 7%. This compares to our FY18 estimate of 2% LFL, impacted by the loss of the Starbucks contract in the US - legacy spread over FY18. As Peacock is almost 80% of the US business, and growth is being driven by Peacock and not US-legacy, we think this indicates Peacock grew volumes high single-digits in the quarter. A large part of the Peacock business is cost pass-through, so volume growth is a better indicator of growth dynamics than revenue, which might get impacted by raw material deflation in any quarter. This is an encouraging performance. Company says that US tax cuts will likely benefit the company. Company says that recent GBP/USD movements will adversely impact translated US profits. Outlook: “The Group anticipates delivering a year of strong growth in FY18 and is well positioned to drive improved profitability, cash flow and returns over the medium term”. Stock trades at P/2018E EPS of 12.4x and EV/2018E EBITDA of 8.5x.

BE11:46am

UBS turning neutral.

BE11:46am

Largely valuation.

BE11:47am

In late November 2017, we upgraded the stock (Note); as (1) we highlighted that given several structural and other challenges were well known – i.e. doctors in UAE, tariffs and patient mix in Switzerland – we thought an inflection point was near as the earnings downgrade cycle slowed, and (2) our analysis suggested that market expectations for long-term margins in Switzerland and Abu Dhabi had become overly cautious. We believe expectations for long-term margins now appear more reasonable/optimistic, while the stock has recovered ~25% since its Nov-17 low. Risk/reward now looks more balanced to us; we move to Neutral from Buy, and look for further evidence of operational delivery to turn more positive. We increase EPS estimates by ~4-6% due to forex adjustments.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

We identify three variables likely to drive margins: (1) patient mix – although having shifted towards lower-margin, basic insured patients (now 47%, vs 32% in 2012), we note this growth has slowed somewhat vs prior years, while margins in FY15-17 held relatively stable despite this mix change; (2) TARMED tariff cut (we estimate a ~150bps impact); and (3) continued IT spend (we estimate a ~10-20bps near-term impact). Based on the above variables, we believe long-term margins could settle at ~17.6%, while we note that market expectations have lifted; now discounting approx. ~17.8% (vs less than 17% previously) – thereby more accurately reflecting the margin pressures.

Our analysis previously confirmed this, but we now see more optimistic long term margin expectations being discounted for Abu Dhabi (~17.5%), below pre-acquisition levels (~20-22%), but roughly in-line with UBSe.

BE11:57am

Given the numerous news reports regarding smartphone market weakness and downward adjustments within Apple’s supply chain, iPhone units and product mix are the main topics on investors’ minds. On the positive side, we believe the manufacturing ramp for iPhone X was the fastest in the company’s history, which likely led to a richer product mix and rising ASP. On the negative side, point-of-sales data suggests overall end demand was weaker than expected, increasing fears of a slower replacement rate (contrary to the Street’s earlier “super cycle” thesis and further exacerbated by Apple’s offer to replace older iPhone batteries). On the supply side, the downward revisions in the supply chain have been broad based, including semiconductor, display, 3D sensor, and assembly/EMS. We now must worry that sell-in was greater than sell-through, thus some excess inventories will pressure near-term forecasts. We lower our CY2018 iPhone unit forecasts, but higher ASPs help offset. More specifically, we are modelling iPhone units/ASPs for December quarter of 80m/USD771 (+2%/+11% y-o-y) and March quarter 54m/USD793 (+6%/21% y-o-y), respectively. We lower our calendar year iPhone unit forecast to 233m or +6.7% y-o-y (vs. +13% prior).

Our bull case scenario suggests upside risk to $230+ versus a downside case of $141, implying risk/ reward is compelling.

We believe gross margins offer the greatest potential source of upside to current consensus estimates through FY18, and to the
perception of earnings growth potential in FY19. Consequently, we expect F1Q gross margin and F2Q gross margin guidance to be the most meaningful data points for investors. iPhone units and ASP will remain critical, however, we expect results and guidance to be relatively in line with our estimates and current buy-side expectations

Important, though fairly obvious, point ......

BE12:00pm

We expect F2Q revenue guidance of $67.5B-69.5B. While iPhone unit demand appears mediocre, we believe iPhone price
increases, continued growth in services, and growth in new hardware accessories (AirPods and HomePod), should allow Apple to guide at least in line with consensus expectations.

Of note, the growing gap between high and low-end iPhone ASPs significantly increases the complexity of implying iPhone units
from revenue guidance. Consequently, revenue guidance is unlikely to provide as clear a signal of iPhone volume as it has
historically.
